Strengths: The course was interesting and the course load was very manageable. Professor Yiengpruksawan (Mimi) is incredibly knowledgable about the topic and deeply cares about her students' education. The fact that many of the pictures used on the lecture slides were taken by Mimi herself testifies to how experienced she is with Buddhist visual tradition and practice.
Weaknesses: At the beginning of the semester, some of the readings were hard to access or find. Eventually the TFs starting making PDF scans of the readings, which really helped.
The class was fun and well organized

This course is well structured between Mimi's lectures and the TA's sections. However, I would have liked more online resources. Many of the course readings were only accessible from books on reserve in the library. This made it difficult to complete them. Additionally, much of the lecture was parallel to or repeating the readings rather than incorporating them in an engaging way.
honestly great class. Cool lectures. Mimi's super knowledgeable

Strengths: very comprehensive, fair exams
Weaknesses: should emphasize Buddhist philosophy more, architecture should be explained in terms of its philosophical underpinnings rather than just having the structure described
If you haven't taken an art history class, I think this is a good class to see if you like that kind of thing.

This was a really chill class with a lot of interesting material, especially if you're interested in Buddhism (which was the reason why I took this class). I feel like I'm able to appreciate Buddhist art a lot more and learned the basics of the different tradition without feeling overwhelmed by the class. Highly recommend!
Yes; I would definitely recommend this to interested students

Mimi is very passionate and knowledgeable about this subject, but the material is quite unfamiliar and lectures tended to be a bit disorganized, which is somewhat challenging for an intro art history course. As an art history major, I would say you should take this class if you are very interested in the subject matter, but if you are looking for a more general art history experience, I think there are some better intro classes.

I would recommend the course to someone who actually wants to engage with art. This is not a gut course as I was led to believe, but I'm really glad I took it! There was a 3 page essay and then a final 10 page paper, as well as 2 midterms where we had to memorize around 70 art pieces for each one, including artist, time period, date, material, and place of origin-- it was not easy! Mimi was a great lecturer and the TA's seemed genuinely engaged with the class.

Yes, I would recommend this to any student who is interested in art history. It was unlike any other art history course I've taken, and it opened my eyes to the diversity of visual expression within a religion context.
